data.message:
I sadly must agree on the last couple Laundry books - I still rather enjoyed them but I feel like maybe Stross is spreading himself too thin. I'm also waiting for Bob to do some more computational demonology. I really wish he'd get back to the business of churning out novels with so many big ideas that they make my head hurt.

Paolo Bacigalupi is an author who IMO does a nice job of juggling both YA and A writing - if anything, I feel like he brings the YA stuff up a notch instead of taking the A down. This has been much appreciated by a clever kid or two who I've turned on to his books. He's been pretty busy on the YA front recently though.
(There's a recent short by Stross (which I think is free) called Equoid, which was fun.)
Oh, I forgot to also denounce Ready Player One, which was the actual Genesis of this post.

Hungry City Chronicles! Sooo good... YA only because there isn't sex. Also because it doesn't feel it has to think too hard about the basic premise. But man oh man the stories and character development are great. :)

I just started Equoid last night... 

Recently read "Daemon" by Daniel Suarez - basically a page-turner for people who are comfortable with TCP/IP. Not life-changing, but enjoyable, and the tech stuff is very well done.

Similar feelings about "Nexus" by Ramez Naam - he does a pretty respectable job with the tech, and the book's enjoyable enough. I didn't find it anywhere near as ground-breaking as others seem to have, but I did enjoy it.

But basically I'm still on the hunt for more swing-for-the-fences, overly ambitious space opera, and there's not enough of that happening right now.

I'm hoping that "On the Steel Breeze" by Alastair Reynolds picks up the momentum that took so long to get established in "Blue Remembered Earth". When he's on, he can be really good. You might also want to check out Peter Watts if you haven't already. Clearly a deeply intelligent dude, and I've like the stuff I've read by him.
I liked Zoo City, I read that last year. More strange fiction than science fiction...
Zoo City was good - Lauren Beukes has a new book out if i recall correctly. Haven't had a chance to get to it yet.
I was not blown away by The Martian or Ready Player One, either.  I really, really loved John Birmingham's "Without Warning" trilogy.  Alternate history stuff.

The entire purpose of Ready Player One seemed to be nostalgic,  not to tell a good story. YA is definitely dumbed down, both in the writing and the plots; in particular most authors tend to hand-feed clues to make mysteries/ twists obvious. I think this is getting worse over time and not just because I'm an older, more sophisticated reader... the writing of The White Mountains still holds up, for example.
I'm going to find my old Christopher pike books from way back when-that was some wacky stuff

I can recommend the Culture novels by Iain M. Banks, excellent writing, solid plot development, well motivated characters. I also recently read Shadow Man by Melissa Scott (from the mid-90s), and found it thought provoking (though not well plotted).
Perdido Street Station by China Mieville is another oldie but goodie.
I have devoured the Culture novels. They are great. (Banks' sudden death is sad.)
I'm still working my way through the Virga books, which I've really enjoyed.
CJ Sansomes Matthew SHardlake series.  HIGHLY recommend!
Read "Sun of Suns" and "Queen..." and thought they were pretty good. But I didn't buy the next one so maybe I didn't like them enough... Or maybe there was no sequel at that time...
I just finished "The Sunless Countries", and will soon go to the next one - more and more of the universe unfolds in each book, and things are definitely not as they seemed at the start.

message:
Book rant incoming...

I thought both "Wool" and "The Martian" were fine, but neither were amazing works. The plots were fine, but I felt the language in both was bland, simple, and by-the-numbers. Many have been lavishing those books with high praise, and I just don't see it. I've also felt the same sort of twinge regarding Charlie Stross' last couple Laundry novels. And I liked Steelheart, but it was also simple (of course, that's a YA title so maybe I got what I paid for).

I also note that I've been reading these as ebooks rather than paper books and I wonder if that is coloring my perception of the writing itself. I'm not a terribly discerning reader; I don't need my genre fiction to be "Literature" (whatever that might be). But I feel like something is missing.

Another possibility is that many of my favorite authors are writing YA now (instead of "Adult") fiction and it affects all their work. In the abstract, I don't mind this as I don't require taboo topics and themes (sex, graphic violence, four-letter words) in my reading. But I wonder if authors are also pulling back on the structure of and language in their books as well. If so, I think that's a mistake; I didn't need my books dumbed down structurally when I was a teen.

Related: I'm looking for suggestions for some recent-ish scifi to read. Any suggestions?

(I should note that the writing in the Wool series improved markedly by the last book.)
